content: Hello, I am a second-year mathematics student, and I would like to improve myself in Lean. Although I am good at mathematics, I’m not exactly sure how to apply this knowledge in Lean. Do you have any suggestions or resources you could recommend?
The natural number game is often cited as a first introduction to proofs in Lean specifically. I enjoyed it.

Are there any specific areas you're interested in?

I’m currently interested in analysis, abstract mathematics, and algebra. I have a solid mathematical background in these areas, but I’m still new to Lean and not sure how to learn it effectively.
the fastest way to learn is probably to ask a lot of basic questions here as you tackle a basic goal (i.e. a basic definition/theorem from your area of interest)
even if it's already done it can still be good practice

Kenny Lau dedi:

the fastest way to learn is probably to ask a lot of basic questions here as you tackle a basic goal (i.e. a basic definition/theorem from your area of interest)

Is there a place where I can study how proofs are written? Where can I find the examples you mentioned?
I've been using mathlib itself as a source of proof examples
But that was only useful to me once I'd done some of the natural-number-game style tutorials, which gave me enough vocabulary that I could start understanding what the mathlib proofs were about

I also will say that exploring a proof inside a lean development environment where you have "jump to definition" and type-checking overlays was tremendously better than just looking at raw examples as text

@İmran Tanq is there an example of a favorite theorem of yours in the fields you mentioned? It doesn't have to be super important or difficult, just any result where you understand the proof "on paper" well might be a good start.

I don't find the Mathlib source to be a good source of proof examples - the proofs there are often term-proofs instead of tactic proofs, and they were obviously obtained by experts who know the library inside out. As one who is still trying to learn, I don't find them very useful as learning tools.

What I find useful (even though I still have not written anything remotely significant) is to find a small theorem I'd like to prove, write down a reasonably detailed paper proof (and it's never detailed enough), and go hunting through Mathlib for the theorems that might help justifying the various steps in my proof. At least, it lets you see how many things are done on the library/API level.

And yes, doing all this with a Lean environment nearby is a really good idea. Jumping to the definitions in the source code is a huge plus, and trying out examples also. Which is a pity, because the environment where I like to think about my proofs is at a café, with a pen and notepad at hand - usually far from a computer with (hopefully) large screens to display all the useful documentation.
